question: What? No bacon? Whatever.
answer: Lincoln ! Over here!

question: Hello , stranger.
answer: What? You don't recognize me?

question: It's just an expression, that's all.
answer: You and your expressions, Lincoln. Now sit down and ask me where I've been.

question: Okay, Ester. Where have you been?
answer: At the medical center. Just for tests but they had me on liquid nutrition.

question: Exciting.
answer: That's not the exciting part. I got my first trimester report

question: Us?
answer: My baby... It's in perfect condition. I just hope I can keep it that way. I still have six months to delivery.

question: Then you leave all this behind, huh?
answer: Why? Will you miss me?

question: I'll miss your coffee. C'mon, I already burned up my quota.
answer: Okay. But this is the last time. What is it?

question: Give me some more of your coffee. Hudson Four-Alpha; profile reviewed. Match to vacancy; 171, Sector 5. Request clearance to populate.
answer: You know that guy who won the Spin in your sector? Starkweather?

question: No.
answer: I had a bout with him last week. Guess how long he's been here? Six months.

question: Six months?
answer: You don't believe me - look it up.

question: Census File
answer: What do you say now? Still think The Spin's rigged for the long haulers?

question: He got lucky, that's all.
answer: And don't you wish it was you... out there on The Island... nature's own clean air zone... no screening, no quotas... unlimited pleasure...

question: Shut up, Jonesy.
answer: Why don't you make me? In the ring.

question: You're out of my weight-class.
answer: Not anymore. They just got the new program in - multi-weight balancing.

question: I'll think about it.
answer: C'mon, champ. A stim unit says you won't last three rounds.

question: Whoooooo!
answer: Sure you input the right weight class?

question: You're just too slow, Jonesy.
answer: You're faster `cause you're lighter. Programmers... they always miss something.

question: Hey, you put up, now pay up.
answer: So make it a beer and a Vita Cola. You know, you're going to get yourself contaminated one of these days.

question: Shut up, Jonesy.
answer: So, you up for a rematch tomorrow?

question: I can't. I got an interact.
answer: With who? That blonde again?

question: Hey, it's an authorized interaction. We're on the same meditation program.
answer: You want to get flagged for proximity?

question: No law against friendship, Jonesy.
answer: Quick . . . Give me that beer back. What's going on, officer?

question: What happened? You lost count? Vita Cola all the way, officer. Accept.
answer: Lincoln? I missed you at breakfast.

question: I guess I overslept.
answer: I just wanted to check we're still on for tonight. The interact.

question: Right. I'll be there.
answer: I'll see you then. Enjoy your day!

question: Just juice today. I'm late for work. C'mon, Kleinwort... So what's up with the Censors, huh? I know what it is. I've just never seen them out in this sector before. What are you saying? They lost someone? Census File Accomodation Status Hey , Jonesy. Remember the guy who won The Spin yesterday? His apartment's still showing as occupied.
answer: So?

question: So you get 24 hours to move out.
answer: Maybe the system didn't update yet.

question: No. It updates on the hour. If he's gone it should be showing a vacancy.
answer: What? You think he's still here? The guy wins a place on The Island and you think he just decided not to go?

question: I don't know. He wasn't there to step up. And now there's a census check...
answer: And now nothing. It's probably the programmers messing up.

question: Maybe.
answer: A stim unit says I can prove it. Cross reference with sanitation.

question: Sanitation Status
answer: See ? Standard procedure. They got to sweep it for the next occupant.

question: Still in the electrical phase, sir. I'll take care of it.
answer: Sorry, chief. I can't let you get any closer. We got live wires over there. What's that you said?

question: I said I can't hear you. M c C o r d c h u c k l e s at the irony.
answer: He y , you get yourself contaminated, don't come pointing the finger at me.

question: How are you doing, Mac?
answer: You know how it is. `Gets to the end of shift, `crew starts draggin t h e i r feet.

question: We l l the guys upstairs are griping about the backlog. They want to know when you'll be ready for move in.
answer: I guess if we bust our backs, we could be out of here by the end of the week.

question: I'll tell them two weeks.
answer: Thanks , chief. I appreciate that.

question: So . . . got any stuff on you today? I t ' s too bad.
answer: What do you mean?

question: T h a t your shift's almost over.
answer: You mean, these things? Well, these things ain't good for you anyways.

question: The y taste good. I like coming here. Talking. Most outsiders don't like to talk.
answer: That's because we ain't supposed to. They got rules about fraternization.

question: What do you do when the shift's over?
answer: M o r e of the same. They cycle us onto the disposal detail. Hump `n dump crew.

question: H u m p `n dump crew?
answer: D e b r i s clearance. We hump the heavy stuff to a site on the outside.

question: Is it as bad as they say out there? The air... the containments.
answer: Right.

question: But not everywhere. Not on The Island.
answer: I don't know too much about that. Lincoln eyes him narrowly. McCord p a u s e s , then tucks his lighter into the cigarette box and offers it with a palliative smile. He y , take it from me, you got a sweet deal right here. So why worry, huh? Lincoln shrugs, accepting the gift with a slow exhale of smoke. We tilt up to follow the smoke plume, dissipating into the fans.

question: N e w Gaza. Yes, very good oncology unit. I t doesn't get any prettier, does it? But this is not a freakshow, my friends. This is a war museum. A history of our battles with mortality... and defeats. Take the stem cell, for instance. A bid to cultivate human parts for transplant - in rodents, primates, barnyard animals. It's enough to make your skin crawl. In some cases literally, giving rise to a new range of cross-species viruses. But that's how we learn. From our mistakes. The y turn a corner. Another hall of windows, portals onto tanks of amber fluid that might be formaldehyde. Suspended within are embryos, fetuses and infants. All human. All grotesquely mutated. C a s e in point, the clone. Back in the beginning, the mapping of the human genome was declared a historic landmark- t o break the curse of heredity, to correct congenital defect... genetic engineering became the brave new world of medical science. A bright future that led to a dark age and much of the legislation we know today. But while the clone laws may have narrowed the field, science marches on. Only to hit the same wall over and over again - the enigma of growth, the alchemy that takes us from embryo to adult. A clone barely reaches infancy before its growth enzymes misfire, resulting in the kind of monstrosities - which are only effigies - you see here. So what do we learn from our mistakes? That human parts cannot grow outside a human body. That human bodies cannot grow outside nature's grand design.
answer: S o what the hell are we doing here?

question: L e t ' s say one day you go to your doctor for a checkup. He discovers you have imminent renal failure and require a kidney transplant. What would you do?
answer: I wouldn't do nothing. My brother'd g i v e me one of his. Or else.

question: E v e n if your brother's kidney is with- o u t defect, there's still a 38% chance of rejection. Or less if he's your twin.
answer: He's not. He's older.

question: But what if you did have a twin? What if you had a genetic double who'd give you not just one of his kidneys, but both? In fact, any organ or body part you ever had cause to need?
answer: What ? You mean like a clone? I thought you said all that stuff was a bust.

question: I said the problem with a clone is it doesn't survive infancy. The solution is to find a different starting point. Why sow the seed when you can create the fruit? Or what we like to call... an "agnate". An agnate is sequenced from a point on the cellular timeclock. I t is spawned post-maturate. It is `created' adult.
answer: L e t me see if I got this straight. You can create this whatever... this walking spare parts holder... but I gotta w a i t five years to get hold of em?

question: The spare parts, as you put it, need to be tested for integrity. But as many of our clients leave it till late in life to take out the policy, we do offer the option for early harvest. Given the risks, however, a waiver is required.
answer: S o five years or no warranty? For the premiums you're asking?

question: You wanted to see me?
answer: Yes . Please, take a seat. He taps a button. The glass wall frosts over. It's unnerving but Lincoln stays deadpan, moving the chair before taking a seat. Merrick reviews the etherboard How ' s Lincoln Six-Echo today? E v e r y t h i n g going okay?

question: I guess not.
answer: Why do you say that?

question: I f I'm here.
answer: I'm not sure I deserve such a negative association. My job's only to see that you're happy. That everything's okay.

question: Right.
answer: I t sounds like you don't believe me.

question: Why wouldn't I?
answer: I t ' s part of your makeup. To challenge things. To question what's around you.

question: Ah.
answer: P e r h a p s you can utilize that facility by helping me solve a little puzzle. Lincoln shifts, feeling uneasy. Merrick consults the etherboard- You're doing well in most areas - pro- f i c i e n t a t work, exercising rigorously, your last medical puts you in excellent condition. But screening's picked up some deviations. Trace levels, changes in your sleep pattern... I see you've also been burning up your quotas...

question: A r e you saying I'm contaminated?
answer: No.

question: The n what's the problem?
answer: The r e are parameters, Lincoln. When someone starts straying from those parameters, we need to find out why.

question: Why?
answer: Because you - not just you, all of our residents - are special. Because people like me don't get to go to The Island. S o tell me, have you noticed any changes in yourself?

question: No.
answer: What about your sleep pattern? You feel you've been sleeping properly? L e t me put it another way, when you wake up, do you feel... disrupted?

question: Disrupted?
answer: R e s t l e s s , disoriented, uneasy...

question: I don't know.
answer: They're all words in your vocabulary. I know you understand what they mean. Lincoln ' s jaw clenches, patronized. Merrick notes this, resumes- Quotas . . . nutrition. Do you feel like you want more than you're given?

question: I don't know.
answer: Do you have any difficulty staying focused? At work, for instance? H a v e you been experiencing feelings, sensations you don't quite understand?

question: I don't know.
answer: Do you sometimes feel agitated for no apparent reason? Frustrated, angry...

question: That's it.
answer: An g r y ? You feel angry?

question: Right.
answer: When exactly do you feel angry?

question: Now... Lincoln leans forward as if to assert this. Merrick slowly nods like he's just revealed something. He taps the etherboard-
answer: I'm going to order some tests at The Medical Center. In the meantime, I'd like you to stay away from stimulants - protein, sugar, caffeine...

question: I already burned up my quotas.
answer: But I know you can get around them. I'm asking you to cooperate. Not for my sake, Lincoln, but for your own.

question: Is that it?
answer: The r e is one other thing. You have a female friend. "Ester". Your file shows you've been interacting regularly.

question: The r e ' s no law against friendship.
answer: O f course not. We encourage interaction in the hope it'll be of mutual benefit. But given these deviations... let's just say proximity becomes an issue.

question: I know the rules of proximity.
answer: The rules of proximity apply to sexual contact, Lincoln. In this case it goes deeper than that. Ester is entering h e r second trimester. A time of change and emotional confusion. Further inter- a c t i o n might be... unhealthy for you. Lincoln , patronized, looks away. This pill he won't swallow. An d for Ester - well, she has only six months left to delivery. Then she'll move out to The Island and whatever ties she has here will be broken. G o o d . Now I'm also going to refill your pleasure quota. It may help to settle you down a little.

question: Thank you. I feel much better now.
answer: I'm not sure you do. But I think you'll do what's right, Lincoln. You may not trust me. But I trust you.

question: S o r r y I'm late.
answer: I t ' s okay. I was waiting to tell you something anyway. Guess what? M y baby - I felt it move. And it's the weirdest feeling too. I can't explain it. It's like being more... more h e r e . Lincoln returns a deadpan look. Ester's smile wavers a little. I'm sorry. I'm all excited and we're supposed to be finding peace of mind.

question: I have to cancel, Ester.
answer: S o I'll see you at breakfast tomorrow?

question: I don't think so. Ester ' s smile falls. Her eyes, reaching, trying to understand.
answer: Did I do something wrong, Lincoln?

question: K a r l . . . Welcome back.
answer: I forgot how much I hate the air here.

question: J u s t a histamine reflex. Your system's readjusting to the sterile environment.
answer: I t ' s the smell I hate. Empty.

question: Yes , well I cut short your leave for a reason. I take it you've been briefed?
answer: O n e of our lab rats is missing. W i t h a dour look, Merrick slots his etherboard i n t o a dock. A proxy resolves over the console, quarter scale, spinning in 3D; male, African American, bull neck. Data etches across thin air:

question: His name is Starkweather Two-Delta. He dropped off the ether two days ago. At first we thought it was a system error. Then we found this in a garbage chute.
answer: D e l t a generation, huh?

question: That's right.
answer: I t was a Delta the last time.

question: T h a t was entirely different. The product suffered a head injury.
answer: What happened to this one?

question: We don't know. He just disappeared.
answer: N o t easy to disappear. Unless he figured a way through the boundary.

question: He's a code two, Karl. A low functioner.
answer: I f you ask me, it's a mistake giving them any functions at all.

question: The y don't function mentally, they don't function physically - you know that.
answer: The n perhaps if you're going to breed lab rats, you should breed them tame. His look, albeit from a distance, throws a stone. Merrick hardens-

question: I f you bothered to read the clone laws, you'd realize we have no choice in the matter. The virtual humanity statutes accord them a set of freedoms. All we can do is prescribe the limits. And even those are subject to regulation. Scope of knowledge, range of activity, even their speech patterns. The law requires that what is of human origin be provided with human characteristics.
answer: You mean, like fallibility? Merrick pauses. He's not going to take the bait.

question: The ether shows no attempts on the boundary. He's here, Karl. But for some reason, your men seem unable to find him. It's your job to contain the products. I'd like you to do it, okay?
answer: A little sensitive, aren't we?

question: J u s t after Starkweather went missing, his sponsor placed an order. An order we can't fill. Damn right I'm sensitive.
answer: A l r i g h t . How much time do I have?

question: J a m i l Starkweather . . . last week he sustained a hepatic trauma resulting in liver hemorrhage. In medical terms, we have maybe a few weeks. In legal terms, we're already o n borrowed time... An d Karl?
answer: R e v e r s e map. Crop to twelve hour segments. Then put up a sub-grid.

question: You want to tell me what's going on?
answer: There's nothing going on, Karl.

question: I'm jaded. Not stupid.
answer: What's your point?

question: I checked up. In the past year, three products have destabilized. All of them Deltas... and there's nothing going on?
answer: You're jumping to conclusions.

question: Once I can overlook. Twice I can call coincidence. Three times I start giving a shit. Because if these products are defective...
answer: Q u a l i t y control is not your concern.

question: S o it is a quality control issue?
answer: That's not what I said.

question: He was in the subway tunnels for two days. In the dark, no food, no water. His fingers were scraped to the bone. He was trying to dig his way out. Now you try to explain to me why that is.
answer: It's not an exact science - biogenesis. There's a degree of trial and error. If the agnate doesn't come together on the first pass, we have to abort and start over. It's like breaking inertia. The bioreactor, the growth medium - we just keep upping the levels till we achieve integration. At which stage the agnate is deemed physically stable. We rely on foundation to provide mental stability - matching the templates to their capacity but walling it in with parameters. When signs of instability started to show up, it pointed to foundation. A hole in the wall, an oversight. But it was only happening in the later generat- ions . Which pointed back to biogenesis.

question: So there was a production defect.
answer: Actually the opposite. We found out in the later generations, the levels were so high that when we broke inertia, the process kept going. Over-integrating. Specifically the neural system. It produced a condition called synesthesia.

question: Synesthesia...
answer: A fusion of the senses, creating a component awareness. Sixth sense, s e c o n d sight, whatever you want to call it. Its emergence seems to be arbitrary. But it gives them experiences beyond their functional parameters. And ultimately... it destabilizes them. However, if we catch it early enough we can control it with re-conditioning. You find this amusing?

question: Poetic.
answer: Poetic?

question: This "agnate" took off just before his sponsor placed an order. Maybe he got the sense his days were numbered...
answer: This stays between you and me, Karl. I trust I can rely on your cooperation?

question: Don't you mean my complicity?
answer: Remind me, why is it you were discharged from the military?

question: What's your point?
answer: Learn to be a team player, Karl. Or you'll find yourself out of another job.

question: Accept. The etherscreen resolves Lincoln's face, dishevelled, urgent-
answer: Ester . . . I have to talk to you.

question: Lincoln ? Are you okay? I was worried.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: The contamination warning. Somebody said you'd been exposed.
answer: I want you to meet me as soon as you can. But you can't tell anyone.

question: Is it true? Were you contaminated?
answer: You know where to come. Jonesy. . .

question: You know where to come. Jonesy. . .
answer: Hey, champ. Are you alright? I heard there was a contamination scare.

question: I saw what happened to him.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Starkweather . . . What they did to him. They cut him open, Jonesy. The y took him upstairs and they cut him open.
answer: You caught that fucking p a t h o g e n , didn't you? You're contaminated.

question: J o n e s y , listen to me... But Jones just backs away. Lincoln makes to follow. Then stops dead in his tracks. Across the avenue, TWO CENSORS are on patrol and his best friend is now heading towards them. With a barren, torn grimace, Lincoln turns away and melts back into the crowd.
answer: Please . . . don't come any closer. I don't want to get contaminated.

question: Ester, I'm not contaminated.
answer: But they said...

question: I'm not contaminated! Contaminants, pathogens... it's just what they tell us to keep us inside.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I saw it. Why they keep us here. To use us. To take things from us.
answer: You're not making sense.

question: Your baby... they're going to take your baby away... you understand?
answer: M y baby? Why would they do that?

question: I don't know! But I saw it!
answer: You're scaring me, Lincoln... I want to go back now.

question: You can't go back! Don't you get it?
answer: Don't hurt him! Lincoln?

question: Good morning, gentlemen.
answer: Thank you for coming out here.

question: Well when Henry called me I got the sense it wasn't for a social visit. I understand there was an incident?
answer: First, let me stress there's no way we could have anticipated what happened...

question: We're on the same team, Mr. Merrick. Just give me the facts down-and-dirty.
answer: We'v e lost two of our products. They escaped containment last night.

question: How exactly did this happen?
answer: We'r e still piecing it together.

question: Containment is one of the terms of our state health license. The fact it was compromised could put us in violation.
answer: Bureaucracy.

question: Henry , it was a bloody battle getting our license through in the first place.
answer: They're not going to pull our license, Ellen. We have a lot of friends on the Commission. Not to mention the goodwill we earned in DC when we took over the facility; a bunker complex for a bio- chemical war that never happened... We relieved them of a costly embarrassment.

question: I'm not sure we can rely on that.
answer: Alright . What do you suggest?

question: First, I need you to level with me. What are our chances of finding them?
answer: Well, in our favor, they've never been outside containment. They'd have no coordinates, no sense of direction.

question: I don't see how that's in our favor.
answer: They're in the middle of the desert. Food and water become an issue.

question: So they might return to the trough?
answer: Possibly.

question: And if not? How long could they last?
answer: A few days maybe. But there is another variable. We maintain the products in a sterile environment. So basically their immune systems are untested. Toxins, pathogens, environmentals t h e rest of us overcome routinely, to them...

question: Even so, the worst may not happen.
answer: We haven't even touched on the worst. If these products reach a populated area, there's the problem of scrutiny.

question: Ellen , we operate under State license on a lease from the Federal Government...
answer: We slipped through a loophole in the clone laws, Henry. And they only let u s through because they smelt money. And they gave us a government basement to cover their own a s s e s not ours. It's at the core of our license - why we screen potential sponsors, why we make them sign discretion agreements, why containment is such a critical factor - to limit the extent of public scrutiny.

question: E i t h e r way, it's unlikely they'd get that far. It's at least twenty miles to the next settlement. Right, Bernard?
answer: Something to add, Mr. Merrick?

question: Hello? Can I help you?
answer: My friend... she needs water.

question: Got stuck in that supercell, didya? Supercellstorm , that's what they call it on the news anyways. I n my day, we just called `em "big ol' h o w l e r s " . Yep, I heard it shut down some of the lodeways. Dust in the works, I guess. Where were you folks headed anyways?
answer: Away.

question: A w a y ? You mean, like outta s t a t e ?
answer: " O u t of state"...

question: N o w where's my manners gone? I'm Ozzie. Osmund r e a l l y . But folks call me Ozzie. S o m e t i m e s I like to make a joke of it, my last name bein' D e e r . . . "O. Deer". We l l now, looks like yer g i r l f r i e n d ' s made herself at home. Yer girlfriend sure is pretty. So what's with them tattoos, huh? Hey , in the eye of the beholder, right? Now this place, this is beautiful to me. This is my place. I own it. `May not look like much but you'd be surprised. C'mon, lemme show you... M o s t a t h i s heavy stuff's industrial scrap. Comes in from all over. Easy way round the recyclin' l a w s . Me, I sell it on to the boondock b o y s for meltdown. Other stuff, I pick up at the scrap markets. Fix it up, `fetches a price. Fossil fuel transport. This piece o' junk's a collector's item. All that Age of the Wheel nostalgia, "elegant era of transport" bullshit. I find the parts, she's as good as solid gold. Now this here's got a colorful history. Came in from this ol' g o v e r n m e n t bunker out in the valley. `Got shut down way back. Then this new outfit took over, stripped the place out. I guess they're doin' s o m e more remodelling cause I just had `em in again the other day... Hump`n dump crew. Nice fellas. You okay there?
answer: I'm going to check on my friend. What are you doing?

question: Nuthin . I wasn't doin nuthin . I knew it... them clothes... them weird tattoos... I mean, I heard stories from those guys but I never... N o t that I believe `em... buncha c r a z y stories... nuthin t o do with you... W h a d d y a s a y we just forget about it, huh? How about I go getcha a beer? What e v e r you want... Just take it... Whaddya w a n t . . . ? You want money...? I t ' s all I got... Take it... just please... just don't hurt me...
answer: " O u t of state" - how do I get there?

question: Which one of you is Diggs?
answer: That's me, slick. This here's my partner Burdon. Don't mind him. He gets a little shy around strangers.

question: What happened to his arm?
answer: `Pursuit last week. The guy took a swing at him with a fireaxe. Didn't stop Burdie though . `Took down that fucker with one arm, didn't you?

question: You don't look like bounty hunters.
answer: Well we're on the job, see? And it kind of helps if you bleed in. You don't look like a bondman either.

question: I'm just an intermediary.
answer: Now that's what people use when they don't want to get their hands dirty.

question: I was told you also handled civil bonds. Debt runners, data-thieves...
answer: What we hunt depends on the bounty.

question: It's worth ten platinum. Unmarked.
answer: What's the bond?

question: The parties I represent want to limit the specific details. But let's just say industrial secrets are involved.
answer: Ten platinum. Must be big secrets.

question: Any good at keeping them?
answer: Oh, me and Burdie, we're busy bees. We don't have time to file every report and we got real bad memories. But just so we understand each other, slick, we're talking about a bag job, right? What's up with these tattoos? They look like fucking boondock types .

question: All I'm authorized to tell you is they have no records in this state. Also that they're not armed or dangerous.
answer: How about we start with their names?

question: John and Jane Doe...
answer: You're kidding me, right? No names? The n - with all due respect - how the fuck d o you expect us to find them?

question: Because you won't have to look. They jumped an overnight shuttle. They'll be headed for the terminal, trying to get out of state. It's strictly a recovery job. For you, it should be childsplay.
answer: The n why not do it yourself? Or is the dog ring just to impress the ladies?

question: The parties I represent want to stay at arm's length. And just so we understand each other that means no connection, no papertrail, no police interest...
answer: Is that everything?

question: . . . no mistakes. They want these two brought in quickly and quietly and unharmed. Once you have them, you'll contact me for further instructions.
answer: I don't know. What do you say, Burdie?

question: I t ' s going to be okay, Ester.
answer: Is it?

question: We just need to get out of state. I told you to stay with me.
answer: I'm hungry.

question: S u n n a v a b i t c h ! What the fuck d o we do now, huh? They could be anywhere...
answer: We go back to the office and run `em.

question: A s what? John and Jane Doe?
answer: We ask the guy.

question: Y e a h , let's tell him we couldn't hack it in kindergarten. See how long him and his ten platinum stick around.
answer: I t was blue, right?

question: What?
answer: The y were using a blue currency card.

question: We l c o m e to Grey Dolphin Bus Lines. What is your destination, please? I t ' s okay. Really. I get that a lot. I'm sorry, now where were we again?
answer: I want to get out of state. Now.
speaker1: T I C K E T CLERK

question: B e l i e v e me, I know how you feel. So where did you want to go exactly?
answer: O u t of state...
speaker1: T I C K E T CLERK

question: J u s t wherever the wind takes you, huh?
answer: Where's that?
speaker1: T I C K E T CLERK

question: We l l , if it was me, out to the west coast. It's perfect this time of year. T r a v e l l i n g alone, are we?
answer: N o . With her.
speaker1: T I C K E T CLERK

question: I can't... I can't breathe... my throat... it's so... dry...
answer: I ' l l find you some water. I t ' s going to be okay, Ester.

question: N o . . . no, it isn't...
answer: I ' l l find you some water, okay?

question: An d then what, Lincoln?
answer: I ' l l find another way. Out of state.

question: An d then what? What if they find us?
answer: The n we'll keep going.

question: I can't... I can't run anymore...
answer: We ' l l keep going till we get there.

question: The Island... You mean, The Island?
answer: N o w I'm going to get some water. But I want you to stay here. It'll be safer.

question: The man, the man up there. Who is he? The juggernaut...
answer: Hi there! I'm Tattletail! What e v e r you want to know, wherever you want to go, I got the answers! Let's look at the menu! N o w let's make a selection!

question: Residential...
answer: Please give me the name.

question: Starkweather...
answer: Okay! Let me find that listing for you! I'll be with you in two shakes! Starkweather , Jamil... I'm sorry! This listing is blocked from the directory! You want me to find another listing? Lincoln looks at the snake, flicking its tongue, coiling.

question: We ain't open for another hour.
answer: Y e a h , well we ain't in the market.
speaker1: G U N S H O P OWNER

question: E v e r y o n e ' s in the market, pal. One end of the barrel or the other...
answer: We ' r e chasing up a currency record from last night. These two ring a bell? D i g g s displays two digital slides. The owner pauses, suspicious.
speaker1: G U N S H O P OWNER

question: What are you? Cops? Lawyers? D i g g s answers by jerking out the rainmaker. The twin barrels aimed at his head, the gunshop o w n e r loses his cool a little- H i m , I remember... Came in just before closing... wanted a shooter but didn't have no ID... settled for one of these.
answer: Did he give you a name?
speaker1: G U N S H O P OWNER

question: No.
answer: Did he say where he was going?
speaker1: G U N S H O P OWNER

question: Oh, Jesus...
answer: Who are you?

question: The y said... I'd never have to see you.
answer: Who? Lincoln takes another step closer. Tom takes another step back.

question: The people...
answer: What people?

question: Look, if you don't get out of here right now, I'm calling security... Why are you here? What do you want?
answer: I want to know...

question: One of the partners at my firm... he told me about it. Gave me a referral. I thought he was joking at first. I went out there, took the sales tour. Even before that I knew it wasn't a joke. There was this discretion agree- ment. I never saw anything like it and I've seen a lot. Ironclad... breathe a word and they've got you by the balls. I don't know... There's cancer in my family. Maybe it was just to keep up. All the partners were on the policy.
answer: The policy?

question: Christ, you have no idea, do you?
answer: About what?

question: I can't fucking do this...
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Insurance. You're an insurance policy.
answer: What is that?

question: Health insurance... medical...
answer: What does that mean?

question: If I get sick... if part of me gets sick... I take a healthy part from you.
answer: Why?

question: How do you expect me to answer that? It's just how it works, that's all. What do you want? A fucking apology?
answer: Why do I look like you?

question: Because you are me . . .
answer: I don't understand.

question: Because they made you from my cells...
answer: Made me?

question: That's right. You were made. Cooked up in a centrifuge like a fucking boiled egg. Every thought running through your head, every word coming out of your mouth, all of it, manufactured, made...
answer: You . . . you're the one who made me?

question: No.
answer: Who made me?

question: I signed a contract. I can show you. It's all right there. Who, why... Look you've got what you wanted. Now why don't you just get out of here?
answer: There are men out there, looking for us. I want you to make them stop.

question: I can't... I can't. Look, I'm a lawyer, I know how it works. The contract, everything, it's all laced with confidentiality clauses. It means they don't want this to get out. It means whatever I do, they're not going to stop. You understand?
answer: Do you have transport?

question: Transport , yes... yes, parked downstairs... Bay 53... Take it...
answer: And then you'll call security?

question: I was looking for water.
answer: Not the best place to look.

question: My transport... it stopped working.
answer: I see. And where were you going?

question: Out of state... What is this place?
answer: It is a sacred place. My people come here to commune with their spirits. Not easy to understand perhaps. For us, the spirit is like the shadow on the rock. Sometimes close, sometimes far away, sometimes the sky clouds and the shadow fades. We come here to ask our spirits to return to us. The man... He speaks to The Grandfather from whom all spirits are born. The Great Spirit who binds every living thing. He has no name. But he is everywhere. In the sun and the moon, the wind and the rain... Now he asks for the gift of vision that he may see through to the spirit shape of things. To find the spirits of the lost. To bring them into the light...

question: I take it you've heard the news.
answer: The bond agents. Yes. Unfortunate.

question: Unfortunate? We're way past unfortunate, Henry.
answer: I thought we'd covered ourselves.

question: The police won't connect the bond agents to us. But that's not the problem. It's the sponsor.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: His name's Thomas Lincoln. It seems they had a genetic reunion. Not a h a p p y one. It was all I could do to stop him going to the authorities.
answer: I still don't see the problem.

question: He may not want a police involvement but he's already threatened to file suit. And he's one of the biggest litigation attorneys in the city.
answer: That's why we have you, Ellen.

question: I t was a marginal problem. And it was under control - according to Bernard.
answer: That's not the point. Whether or not it's a factor in this instance, it puts us in breach of the clone laws.

question: I t doesn't even touch their genetics.
answer: I'm talking about self-awareness. The virtual humanity statutes require us t o give them consciousness to the l e v e l of functionality. But not beyond. L e g a l l y , we are naked on every level. Federal legislature, state licensing, sponsorship contract... But even if we did manage to weather the legal storm, we'd never survive the public scrutiny.

question: I've spent my entire career facing down naysayers, Ellen. Don't think for a second I'm afraid of facing them now.
answer: You remember cryogenics? At the outset, people dismissed it as a rich man's folly. Eccentric millionaires freezing their brains, hoping to wake up in a new body.

question: A l r i g h t . What do you suggest?
answer: O u r security chief - I've been looking at his file. Ex-marine, served in South China - do we think he still has it in him?

question: A r e you insane?
answer: ` You ever wondered why Henry takes those pills, Bernard? Why he doesn't avail himself of his own technology?

question: An agnate could give me a new heart but to get it to function mentally...
answer: B u l l s h i t , Henry. Bullshit. You don't want to deal with reality. Only with concept. I may not have been there at the start but I heard the stories. You wanted in on every aspect of construction, from environmental design right down to the classical playlists. I t wasn't enough just to make it work, was it? No, you wanted your own little utopia.

question: A r e you quite finished?
answer: E v e n God has blood on his hands, Henry. Are you going to watch it all go up in flames or are you going to deal with it?

question: You see that street down there...? Running east from the stadium. My father used to take me to church on that street. An old Spanish church.
answer: What's your point?

question: What did you give her?
answer: J u s t something to help her sleep. I think she has a bronchial infection. But I'm not sure I should give her an antibiotic in case it effects the baby.

question: S o you know about the baby...
answer: Is n ' t that why you came here?

question: I found your name in the listings. I wasn't sure. You don't look like her.
answer: The y have a plan... For women like me.

question: S o you're the one who takes her baby.
answer: You know when you're young? How you run around thinking you're immortal? The r e was a lodeway accident. I was... damaged. After that, I thought no man would ever want me. I was wrong. His name was John. He said he married me for my eyes. Ocean eyes, he called them. He always loved the ocean. Up there on the wall, that's John's boat. But I think there was always an unspoken regret between us. When we heard about the technology, it was like... forgive- n e s s , like a second chance. A child of our own, part of both of us. Sailing trips, fishing trips, so many plans... J o h n got cancer a year ago. He died. I r o n i c . That the same technology could have saved his life. And now the baby is the only part of him I have left. And the boat. I still have the boat.

question: I told you we shouldn't have gone to outside personnel. They were cowboys.
answer: We had no choice, Karl. We had to keep this away from The Institute.

question: An d now? What's this?
answer: Your resignation papers. Maybe `early retirement' would be more accurate... T e n platinum bounty - if you sign the papers, their loss becomes your gain.

question: A parachute... So there's a jump?
answer: You understand that whatever happens, The Institute must be able to deny it. We use a chemical to dispose of waste product. It's called di-halcyonate. I t reacts on a molecular level to start a process of internal combustion. The subject is incinerated from the inside out. In post-mortem application it's done its job before rigor mortis. In a live subject, well... you can imagine.

question: You want to dispose of your products.
answer: I t ' s a little more complicated than that. We have to be very... thorough. If you still have it in you, that is.

question: Why do you think I still wear this?
answer: I don't know.

question: I was discharged from the marines for insubordination. If you asked anyone i n my unit, they'd call it heroism. I disobeyed an order to fall back. I took out a bunker complex single-handed.
answer: S o you wear it is a badge of honor?

question: N o . It wasn't bravery. I wasn't afraid of dying. I just didn't care. You see, I suddenly realized I was just a sack of flesh with a heartbeat. Life, death, I just couldn't see the point anymore.
answer: You'll find a vehicle parked outside. It's unregistered, difficult to trace. I take it we have an agreement...?

question: What do I call you?
answer: Lincoln . My name's Lincoln.

question: Lincoln , I think she needs professional help. I think she needs to see a doctor.
answer: N o . They'll find her. They'll take her.

question: N o t if I don't want them to.
answer: You don't understand. They don't want people to know about her. Either of us.

question: The doctor I'm thinking of, he's an old friend. He look after John in t h e final stages. I trust him.
answer: Why ? So you can take her baby?

question: N o . No, that's not what I want. O f f Lincoln's blunt look, she sighs, lowering into a chair. M a y b e I didn't realize she'd be so... M a y b e I just didn't want to. Either way, I was wrong. I want you to know that. I was wrong... And I'm sorry.
answer: The y make you believe there's a place called The Island. Then they take you upstairs and put you to sleep. They cut you open. They take pieces of you.

question: E v e n if I had taken her baby, I swear to you, I'd never have... They give you a choice, you see, to extend the sponsorship after... after d e l i v e r y .
answer: N o . I saw a lot of us go to The Island. But I never saw anyone come back.

question: You mean... Even if I had extended the sponsorship, they'd have... and kept taking the money? But that's inhuman.
answer: Is it? I wouldn't know.

question: Yes?
answer: I'm from the Sanger Institute.

question: I've given you people enough of my time already.
answer: I t ' s just a formality. I need to see your sponsorship contract. Is this the only copy?

question: Katherine . . . It's good to see you. I haven't seen you since John's funeral.
answer: We l l I've been keeping busy. Trying to. Thanks for coming down to meet me.

question: Your call was a little cryptic. What is it exactly that's wrong with you?
answer: I t ' s not me... Not exactly.

question: He l l o , stranger.
answer: You look tired, Lincoln.

question: Ester...
answer: I t ' s okay. I know. Katherine told me. She sits up, lowering her mask. Her hand finding his. She told me a lot of things. About how they used a tiny part of her to make me. She said it wasn't so very different.

question: What do you mean?
answer: F r o m this... From having a baby. She told me how they use us... And I keep thinking... about the others... the ones we left behind, about how they'll never know... how they'll... I'm going to be okay, Lincoln.

question: He's come for her. For us.
answer: What e v e r this is about, we can't move her. She's already under sedation.

question: How long before she wakes up?
answer: The procedure takes three hours but...

question: You'll take care of it, won't you? Take her somewhere they can't find her...
answer: Katherine , what the hell's going on?

question: You can stop there. I know why I'm here. You wanted to know if I'm going to sue you for breach of contract.
answer: N o t h i n g so devious, Mrs. Ester. We simply wanted to find some way to heal the wounds from this incident.

question: I don't want restitution, Dr. Sanger. The reason I agreed to this meeting was to have the chance to talk to you.
answer: O f course. Please...

question: S i r , I've been trying to contact you. It's the ether... Something's wrong.
answer: E t h e r c o n ! Ether control, come in! An y o n e ! Somebody pick up!

question: That's what I mean. We can't get through. The circuits are locked.
answer: How wide is this going?
